President
Eisenhower
• on Citizenship Education
(from the New York Times)
President Eisenhower today deplored the fact
that the country’s citizen army was being asked
to fight and resist communism with only a
meager education in the responsibilities of
citizenship.
Recalling General William F. Dean’s incar¬
ceration (by the Communists in North Korea),
the details of which he had learned over the
breakfast table at the White House from the
former 24th Division commander, the President
said he sometimes wondered why more of our
soldiers had not succumbed to Communist
indoctrination.
The President said he felt this way because
of the meager education given our people as
to what their obligation is to a free form of
government, what it means to support it and
what it takes to keep it and pass it on.
The President’s remarks appeared to cover
citizenship training in general.
Dr. George S. Benson is awarded the Freedoms Foundation medal at Valley
Forge by President Dwight D. Eisenhower of Columbia University. The National
Education Program has received more Freedoms Foundation awards than has
any other institution or organization.
